Datasets and Features

Table of Contents

  • Overview

  • Common Table Structure

  • Utility Functions

  • Example: Creating and Deploying Features

    • 1. Create New Feature Module:

    • 2. Add Feature View Definition

    • 3. Deploy Features

Overview

Data (raw OHLCV data, features, backtests, predictions) is stored in BigQuery tables. A Feast feature store is deployed for data retrieval and feature management.

Note

It is recommended to retrieve data from Feast rather than directly querying BigQuery when developing features or strategy functions.

Feature definitions are managed in: src/feast_repo/features_definitions.yaml

Common Table Structure

  • event_timestamp (mandatory)

    Timestamp column following the format ‘YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS±hh:mm’

    Example: ‘2017-01-01 00:00:00’ or ‘2017-01-01 00:00:00+00:00’

  • Entity Columns

    Columns that uniquely identify rows within a specific event_timestamp. Represent primary dimensions like exchange and symbol. Used for joining, merging, and upserting new data.

  • Clustering Fields

    Used for query optimization and efficient data retrieval. Currently set as the union of event_timestamp and entity columns.

  • Table References

    Format: {PROJECT_ID}.{DATASET_ID}.{table_name}

Utility Functions

src.utils.create_bq_table_if_not_exist(...)

Creates a BigQuery table if it doesn't exist with the specified schema and clustering fields.

src.utils.load_to_bq_table(df, table_ref, keys)

Upsert and update missing values from a pandas DataFrame into a BigQuery table with schema evolution support.

src.utils.fetch_from_feature_store(...[, ...])

Fetches historical feature data from Feast feature store within a specified time range and entity constraints.

src.utils.get_max_timestamp_from_bq(table_ref)

Retrieves the maximum event_timestamp from a BigQuery table with optional filtering.
src.utils.create_bq_table_if_not_exist(table_ref: str, schema: List[SchemaField], clustering_fields: List[str] | None = None) → Table[source]

Creates a BigQuery table if it doesn’t exist with the specified schema and clustering fields.

Parameters:

  • table_ref – A reference to the BigQuery table, bigquery table reference format: project_id.dataset_id.table_name

  • schema (list) – The schema definition for the table as a list of google.cloud.bigquery.SchemaField objects.

  • clustering_fields (list, optional) – A list of column names to use for table clustering. Defaults to None.

Returns:

The created or existing BigQuery table object.

Return type:

google.cloud.bigquery.table.Table

Example

>>> from google.cloud import bigquery
>>>
>>> from src.config import BQ_CLIENT, PROJECT_ID, DATASET_ID
>>> from src.utils import create_bq_table_if_not_exist
>>>
>>> table_ref = f'{PROJECT_ID}.{DATASET_ID}.new_table_name'
>>>
>>> schema = [
... bigquery.SchemaField("event_timestamp", "TIMESTAMP"),
... bigquery.SchemaField("exchange", "STRING"),
... bigquery.SchemaField("symbol", "STRING"),
... bigquery.SchemaField("open", "FLOAT"),
... bigquery.SchemaField("high", "FLOAT"),
... bigquery.SchemaField("low", "FLOAT"),
... bigquery.SchemaField("close", "FLOAT"),
... bigquery.SchemaField("volume", "FLOAT")
>>> ]
>>>
>>> table = create_bq_table_if_not_exist(table_ref, schema, ['event_timestamp','exchange','symbol'])
src.utils.load_to_bq_table(df: DataFrame, table_ref: str, keys: List[str]) → None[source]

Upsert and update missing values from a pandas DataFrame into a BigQuery table with schema evolution support.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – The DataFrame containing the data to be loaded into BigQuery.

  • table_ref (str) – The full reference to the target BigQuery table in the format ‘project_id.dataset_id.table_id’.

  • keys (List[str]) – List of column names to be used as clustering fields and merge keys.

Returns:

None

Example

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> from src.config import BQ_CLIENT, PROJECT_ID, DATASET_ID
>>> from src.utils import load_to_bq_table
>>> df = pd.DataFrame({
...     'event_timestamp': [...],
...     'exchange': [...],
...     'symbol': [...],
...     'strategy_prediction': [...]
... })
>>> table_ref = f'{PROJECT_ID}.{DATASET_ID}.prediction_table_name'
>>> keys = ['event_timestamp','exchange','symbol']
>>> load_to_bq_table(df, table_ref, keys)
src.utils.fetch_from_feature_store(from_datetime: str, to_datetime: str | None, feature_refs: List[str], entities: Dict[str, str | List[str]] | None = None) → DataFrame[source]

Fetches historical feature data from Feast feature store within a specified time range and entity constraints.

Parameters:

  • from_datetime (str) – Start datetime for the feature fetch in ISO format (e.g., ‘2023-01-01 00:00:00’).

  • to_datetime (Optional[str]) – End datetime for the feature fetch in ISO format. If None, fetches up to the latest available data.

  • feature_refs (List[str]) – List of feature references in the format ‘feature_view_name:feature_name’.

  • entities (Optional[Dict[str, Union[str, List[str]]]]) – Dictionary of entity filters where: - key: entity column name - value: either a single entity value (str) or list of entity values (List[str]) Defaults to None, which means no entity filtering.

Returns:

DataFrame containing the requested features with columns:

  • event_timestamp: timestamp of the feature values

  • entity columns: as specified in the feature view

  • feature columns: as requested in feature_refs

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

Example

>>> from src.utils import fetch_from_feature_store
>>> feature_refs = ['raw_ohlcv:close', 'template_features:std_log_return_10_close']
>>> entities = {'exchange': ['KuCoin']}
>>> df = fetch_from_feature_store(
...     from_datetime='2024-12-01 00:00:00',
...     to_datetime='2024-12-10 00:00:00',
...     feature_refs=feature_refs,
...     entities=entities
... )

>>> #to get all feature references in a feature view
>>> from src.config import FEAST_STORE
>>> feature_view = FEAST_STORE.get_feature_view("raw_ohlcv")
>>> feature_refs = [f"{feature_view.name}:{feature.name}" for feature in feature_view.features]
>>> entities = {'exchange': ['KuCoin']}
>>> df = fetch_from_feature_store(
...     from_datetime='2024-12-01 00:00:00',
...     to_datetime='2024-12-10 00:00:00',
...     feature_refs=feature_refs,
...     entities=entities
... )
src.utils.get_max_timestamp_from_bq(table_ref: str, entities: Dict[str, str | List[str]] | None = None)[source]

Retrieves the maximum event_timestamp from a BigQuery table with optional filtering.

Parameters:

  • table_ref (str) – The fully qualified BigQuery table reference in the format ‘project_id.dataset_id.table_name’

  • entities (Optional[Dict[str, Union[str, List[str]]]], optional) – Dictionary of column-value pairs for filtering. Values can be either a single string or a list of strings. Example: {‘exchange’: ‘KuCoin’, ‘symbol’: [‘BTC/USDT’, ‘ETH/USDT’]}. Defaults to None.

Returns:

The maximum event_timestamp found in the table. Returns None if

no results are found or if the table is empty.

Return type:

Optional[datetime]

Example

>>> from google.cloud import bigquery
>>> from src.config import BQ_CLIENT, PROJECT_ID, DATASET_ID
>>> from src.utils import get_max_timestamp_from_bq
>>> table_ref = f'{PROJECT_ID}.{DATASET_ID}.ohlcv_daily'
>>> entities = {'exchange': 'KuCoin', 'symbol': ['BTC/USDT', 'ETH/USDT']}
>>> max_timestamp = get_max_timestamp_from_bq(table_ref, entities)
>>> print(max_timestamp)
2024-01-07 00:00:00+00:00

Example: Creating and Deploying Features

This example demonstrates:

  1. Create new feature module:

    1. Get KuCoin raw price data from feature store

    2. Calculate 1 day log returns

    3. load new records / features to database

  2. Add feature view definition

  3. Deploy feature view

1. Create New Feature Module:

import datetime

import numpy as np

from google.cloud import bigquery

import ccxt

from src.config import BQ_CLIENT, PROJECT_ID, DATASET_ID, PROD_DATASET_ID
from src.utils import get_max_timestamp_from_bq, fetch_from_feature_store, load_to_bq_table

def calculate_log_return_feature_set(from_datetime, exchange):
    #feature references follow the format feature_view_name:feature_name
    feature_refs = ['raw_ohlcv:open', 'raw_ohlcv:high', 'raw_ohlcv:low', 'raw_ohlcv:close']
    entities={"exchange": exchange}
    df = fetch_from_feature_store(
        from_datetime=from_datetime,
        to_datetime=None,
        feature_refs=feature_refs,
        entities=entities
    )

    #create 1 day log return price columns
    log_ret_columns = ['log_ret_open', 'log_ret_high', 'log_ret_low', 'log_ret_close']
    price_columns = ['open', 'high', 'low', 'close']
    df[log_ret_columns] = df.groupby('symbol')[price_columns].transform(lambda x: np.log(x).diff(1))
    df.drop(price_columns, axis=1, inplace=True)

    load_to_bq_table(df=df, table_ref=NEW_TABLE_REF, keys=['event_timestamp', 'exchange', 'symbol'])

if __name__ == '__main__':
    NEW_TABLE_REF = f'{PROJECT_ID}.{DATASET_ID}.example_log_ret_features'

    #use below to get exchange name reference by ccxt
    exchange = getattr(ccxt, 'kucoin')().__str__() #kucoin -> KuCoin, kucoinfutures -> KuCoin Futures

    #Production ohlcv_daily table reference
    OHLCV_TABLE_REF = f'{PROJECT_ID}.{PROD_DATASET_ID}.ohlcv_daily'
    latest_timestamp = get_max_timestamp_from_bq(OHLCV_TABLE_REF, entities={"exchange":exchange})
    #>>datetime.datetime(2025, 1, 7, 0, 0, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)
    from_datetime = (latest_timestamp - datetime.timedelta(days=1)).__str__()
    #>>'2025-01-07 00:00:00+00:00'
    calculate_log_return_feature_set('2025-01-05 00:00:00', 'KuCoin')

2. Add Feature View Definition

Add new feature view to src/feast_repo/features_definitions.yaml:

feature_views:
  log_ret_ohlc:
    description: description
    entities:
      - symbol
      - exchange
    ttl:
      days: 1
    source:
      type: bigquery
      table: example_log_ret_features
      production: false
    features:
      - name: log_ret_open
        dtype: Float64
      - name: log_ret_high
        dtype: Float64
      - name: log_ret_low
        dtype: Float64
      - name: log_ret_close
        dtype: Float64

3. Deploy Features

Run the following command:

python3 -m src.feast_repo.create_store

Now the deployed features and feature view can be retrieved from feast feature store

feature_refs = [
    'log_ret_ohlc:log_ret_open',
    'log_ret_ohlc:log_ret_high',
    'log_ret_ohlc:log_ret_low',
    'log_ret_ohlc:log_ret_close'
]

# Example usage with fetch_from_feature_store
df = fetch_from_feature_store(
    from_datetime='2025-01-05 00:00:00',
    feature_refs=feature_refs,
    entities={"exchange": "KuCoin"}
)
